Generally ~1 to thoroughly read the article(s) for the week. Presentation weeks were more like ~3-4.
2-4 hours/week

4 hours per week
30 mins to 1 hour
This course is required. Many of the student presentations are not particularly strong!
Think its great EHS does this. At first I found it a chore to come to every week, but now that im graduating i feel like it was an awesome opportunity .

I think this course isn't really necessary for students, especially second year students. EHS is one of the only departments that has mandatory weekly seminars for both years. I understand the importance of learning about current research in the field, but often times some of the subject matter is so out of my area of focus that I don't understand the research and I feel like I could have a better use for my time.
It was nice being exposed to a variety of EHS topics, but the topics could better reflect the interests of the EHS students.
Love getting to discuss environmental health with my peers

The seminar was an improvement over past years in which there was minimal student engagement. I think lack of student engagement is still a problem however; since students do not receive credit for this class, it is difficult to ensure that anyone actually does the reading or pays attention in seminar.
Good overall, but need to be better scheduled. Students' discussion session with the speaker after the seminar conflicted with 1-year Biostatistics II, so it's a waste.

great course
help and encourage me to learn environmental knowledge from different area
good
It really gives us new insight into the hot research topic in environmental health science.

PhD students carried the journal club every week. Unmotivated, disengaged MPH students make the environment less interesting and beneficial for everyone. I don't know if there is a way to get students to engage more, but it makes the experience very frustrating.
I enjoy the variety in this course.
Good

This course give student access to important literature and the researchers who wrote the literature. It is weak in that a majority of the students lack research priorities and the discussion regarding methods can be limited.
interesting academic research papers and seminars
Great learning experience. Its important for us to read papers and understand them. Pizza lunch can make people sleepy though.

Very good course that keeps you abreast of all relevant topics in the public health community and makes you think critically about the methods and experiments that researchers performed so you can apply that critical thinking skills to your own research.
She is great!
LOVE HER!!! Shes the best and shes so smart. She makes us think so critically. I wish I had more time to offer seminar but listening to her speak left me with an impression
Ying is great, out of my EHS professors she is one that tries very hard. She does her best to make the class more engaging and I really commend her efforts!
Ying was extremely helpful and involved in the discussion portion of this seminar.
Doctor Chen is professional and patient
She always promotes thoughtful discussion
very good
She's friendly and have a really good knowledge of environment health sciences.
good
Asked thought-provoking questions, so even when students were quiet I felt like I took away more from the sessions that I did the papers alone
Nice and patient

Ying is fantastic; she is extremely knowledgeable, approachable, and always does her best to engage a crowd who largely refuse to put in the effort the course deserves. She picks interesting and varied literature for us to review, even while being constrained by the seminar series topics.
Dr. Chen always asked interesting questions, and wanted to make sure we saw why the topics were important in the context of the field.
Good instructor
Dr. Chen is very good at stimulating discussion, and probing student with difficult questions. She understands the academic demographic of the course, and assigns papers appropriately.
professor with critical thinking.
Very helpful and knowledgeable about the subject.

Very passionate and efficient instructor. She makes a very nice summary comments at the end of every seminar along with her evaluation with related questions about the paper presented, which makes you think critically about methodology and about other public health problems.
It is required
While Ying is a great instructor, I think the course material itself is really not necessary. When there are so many other things students must do, this is just another lost hour+ a week.
It is a good opportunity to learn about EHS topics and get to know some of the other EHS students.
great way to learn more about environmental health topics

A very helpful seminar
Yes
good
This is a required course for EHS students.
Read the paper
This course provides journal discussion of recent public health, particularly in the field of environmental health. I would suggest that a separate journal club be formed for PhD students.
an overall interesting course with variable environmental health science topics.
I would recommend it to whoever interested in environmental health.
